awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in the Southwest Local Algebra Meeting at the University of North Texas, March 4–5, 2023. The conference will catalyze interactions between students and faculty from institutions throughout the Southwest working broadly in rings, fields, and groups. Algebraists in the region pursue research on a variety of topics under the umbrella of pure and applied algebra, but the geographical distances between institutions make it difficult to establish new collaborations. This meeting will bring together students and faculty from a variety of backgrounds for lively talks, scientific interactions, and professional networking, with ample time to explore new research projects. About 80 – 100 participants are expected from throughout the Southwest and South regions, including graduate students and both junior and senior faculty. The meeting particularly encourages participation of algebraists from groups historically underrepresented in mathematics, as well as nontenured faculty and faculty at non-PhD-granting institutions. 

Algebraic structures are crucial to many branches of mathematics, including coding theory, cryptography, combinatorics, geometry, topology, number theory, and mathematical physics. At this conference, six experts will deliver hour-long talks accessible to graduate students, and students will present research in three hour-long poster sessions. The speakers are specialists in algebraic combinatorics, automorphic forms, homological algebra, algebraic geometry, non-commutative geometry, and both commutative and non-commutative algebra. This variety of interests is expected to bolster creative interactions between participants. More information can be found at the conference webpage: http://www.math.ttu.edu/~lchriste/slam2023.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 13th annual Southwest Local Algebra Meeting (SLAM) occurred at the University of North Texas in Denton, March 4-5, 2023. Junior and senior mathematicians working in algebraic fields from institutions across the Southwest met to share research ideas. 110 participants registered for the meeting, including 72 graduate students and 15 untenured faculty and post-docs.

Previous meetings took place at the UT Arlington in 2010, New Mexico State in 2011, Texas Tech in 2012, the University of Arizona in 2013, Texas A&M in 2014, Oklahoma State in 2015, Texas State in 2016, the University of New Mexico in 2017, the University of Arkansas in 2018, the UT El Paso in 2019, Tulane in 2020, and Baylor in 2022.

Participants met at the University of North Texas for talks on combinatorics, geometry, number theory, and commutative and noncommutative algebra. James Zhang (University of Washington) gave the keynote address, with additional talks by Luigi Ferraro (Texas Tech), Susanna Fishel (Arizona State), Patricia Klein (Texas A&M), Olav Richter (North Texas), and Nathan Williams (UT Dallas). Participants included 91 mathematicians from Kansas, Illinois, Louisiana, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas, Washington, and Oaxaca. NSF funds were used primarily to support travel and lodging for students and faculty with limited local travel support.

There were 26 posters, by 24 graduate students, 1 post-doc, and 1 faculty member. Presenters gave their ideas in discussions with other researchers. The posters were
•    Tatheer Ajani (UT Arlington, On the vanishing of self Tor)
•    Faqruddin Azam (Oklahoma State, Divisor labeling)
•    Austin Bell (University of New Mexico, Interpolation between closures)
•    Reid Buchanan (Oklahoma State, Macaulay coefficients and decomposing lex segments)
•    Hoai Dao (Oklahoma State, Resolving powers of the maximal ideal with a hole)
•    Sudipta Das (Arizona State, Volume = multiplicity formula for p-families of ideal in positive characteristic)
•    Lhexa D'Avignon (North Texas, Action principle for relativistic magnetohydrodynamics)
•    Souvik Dey (University of Kansas, Some characterizations of local rings via reducing homological dimensions)
•    Nestor Fernando Diaz Morera (Tulane, Nearly toric Schubert varieties and Dyck paths)
•    Monalisa Dutta (University of Kansas, Subfunctors of Ext and Ulrich split rings)
•    Zhaobidan Feng (Texas A&M, Reconstructing Braided Subcategories of SU(N)_k)
•    Katie Grebel (UT Arlington, The Koszul homology of minimal intersection rings)
•    Emily Gunawan (University of Oklahoma, Triangulations and maximal almost rigid representations)
•    Dillon Hanson (North Texas, Modular reflection groups and their invariant mixed Forms)
•    Alexis Hardesty (Texas Tech, Realizing differential graded algebra structures on minimal free resolutions)
•    David Lieberman (University of Nebraska, Generalizing Bernstein's inequality for D-modules)
•    Jose Lozano (UT Arlington, The Point Scheme and Line Scheme of a Certain Quadratic Quantum P^3)
•    Ritika Nair (University of Kansas, On the Lefschetz property for quotients by monomial ideals containing squares of variables)
•    Shravan Patankar (UI Chicago, Coherence of absolute integral closures)
•    Sarah Poiani (University of New Mexico, Prereductions, postexpansions, prehulls, and postcores)
•    Jesus Indalecio Ruiz Bolanos (Baylor, Do not go too far to correct your errors)
•    Hannah Solomon (Texas A&M, Working towards a classification of super-modular tensor categories by rank)
•    Cody Tipton (University of Washington, Colored operads and homotopy coherent diagrams)
•    Jonathan Toledo (Instituto Tecnológico Etla, Progress on persistence property)
•    Le Tran (New Mexico State, Initially regular sequences on cycles)
•    Benjamin Warren (Texas A&M, Braid groups, motion groups, and their representations).

Intellectual Merit: The study of rings, fields, and groups is important in many branches of mathematics, e.g., geometry, group representations, number theory, combinatorics, and homotopy theory.

Algebraists in the Southwest study a variety of topics under the umbrella of ring theory. Geographical distances are large, so spontaneous inter-institution interactions rarely occur. SLAM brings together students and faculty from across the region, and includes time to establish new and reinforce ongoing collaborations.

Broader Impacts: The participants came from many types of institutions, and included many underrepresented groups and faculty at all career stages. There were ~60 graduate students, 2 post-docs, 8 untenured faculty, 2 retired faculty, 1 software engineer, and 1 undergraduate. There were 26 women and 9 Hispanic participants.

Many faculty at non-Ph.D.-granting institutions in the Southwest are graduates of local universities. SLAM offered them an opportunity to strengthen contacts. The location and financial support made it possible for them to participate. Researchers who already have national/international collaborations got a chance to learn of advances in the broader area of algebra and connect with colleagues in the region

The small and informal setting offered graduate students a relaxed introduction to professional meetings. The poster sessions in particular were an ice-breaker, conducive to student-faculty interactions. Many students struck up spirited scientific discussions with faculty and students from other institutions, and the meeting was very helpful for students who were on or about to enter the job market.
